answers.answer:
Ukrainian refugees in Romania can receive support in various areas. This includes legal assistance through "Law made simple" to understand rights and obligations, and "PTSD Help" for managing Post Traumatic Stress Disorder.

Support is also available for entry and documentation, including guidance on border crossings, asylum seeking procedures, and travel to other EU Member States, especially for those with biometric passports. Help-lines are provided for CNRR, UNHCR, IOM Romania, and the National Line against Trafficking in Persons.

For minors, unaccompanied children receive care from the General Directorates for Social Assistance and Child Protection (DGASPC), and a national hotline (119) is available for child abuse cases.

Accommodation support is offered through "Un Acoperis" for finding temporary housing. Financial assistance is available at BCR, allowing exchange of UAH-RON, with 0 costs for transactions, account opening, and inter/intra-bank payments, along with a dedicated helpline for financial services.

Emergency help for resources like food, products, clothing, tents, transportation, or volunteers can be requested or offered via "Sprijin de Urgență."

Additionally, there are Regional Centers for Procedures and Accommodation for Asylum Seekers located in Rădăuți, Maramureș, Galați, București, Timișoara, and Giurgiu, providing specific support for asylum processes. General support categories mentioned also include Housing, Education, Health, and Transportation.

Support is also available for entry and documentation, including guidance on border crossings, asylum seeking procedures, and travel to other EU Member States, especially for those with biometric passports. Help-lines are provided for CNRR, UNHCR, IOM Romania, and the National Line against Trafficking in Persons.

For minors, unaccompanied children receive care from the General Directorates for Social Assistance and Child Protection (DGASPC), and a national hotline (119) is available for child abuse cases.

Accommodation support is offered through "Un Acoperis" for finding temporary housing. Financial assistance is available at BCR, allowing exchange of UAH-RON, with 0 costs for transactions, account opening, and inter/intra-bank payments, along with a dedicated helpline for financial services.

Emergency help for resources like food, products, clothing, tents, transportation, or volunteers can be requested or offered via "Sprijin de Urgență."

Additionally, there are Regional Centers for Procedures and Accommodation for Asylum Seekers located in Rădăuți, Maramureș, Galați, București, Timișoara, and Giurgiu, providing specific support for asylum processes. General support categories mentioned also include Housing, Education, Health, and Transportation. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/dopomohaapp

answers.answer: Ukrainian nationals can enter Romania by presenting a valid passport at the border crossing, which allows them to stay for up to 90 days. If they do not have any documents, they can still enter Romania as an asylum seeker. There are two primary methods of entry: with the right of short-stay (requiring a passport) or as an asylum seeker (without documents). Additionally, individuals can apply for asylum within Romania at a later point.
answers.bResponse: Ukrainian nationals can enter Romania by presenting a valid passport at the border crossing, which allows them to stay for up to 90 days. If they do not have any documents, they can still enter Romania as an asylum seeker. There are two primary methods of entry: with the right of short-stay (requiring a passport) or as an asylum seeker (without documents). Additionally, individuals can apply for asylum within Romania at a later point. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/dopomohaapp

answers.answer: The official border crossing points from Ukraine into Romania are Halmeu, Sighetu Marmației, Siret, and Isaccea. It is also possible to reach Romania through the Republic of Moldova.
answers.bResponse: The official border crossing points from Ukraine into Romania are Halmeu, Sighetu Marmației, Siret, and Isaccea. It is also possible to reach Romania through the Republic of Moldova. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/dopomohaapp

answers.answer: Yes, financial assistance and currency exchange are available for new arrivals in Romania. At BCR (Romanian Commercial Bank), Ukrainian nationals with a valid passport can exchange UAH-RON (hryvnia-lei) at the BNR exchange rate, up to 2,000 lei per person. There are 11 BCR branches in border areas that operate 24/7 for cash needs. Additionally, BCR offers financial-banking services with 0 lei costs for transactions made at POS and ATM with cards issued in Ukraine, 0 lei commission for opening and administering a current account, and 0 fees for inter and intra-bank payments. For assistance with financial-banking services, individuals can call 0373514244 or email suport.linia1@bcr.ro.

answers.answer: Unaccompanied children entering Romania can receive help from the General Directorates for Social Assistance and Child Protection (DGASPC) from each county, which are the authorized institutions to take care of them. If there is a suspicion of child abuse, individuals can call 119, a unique national telephone number for such cases.
answers.bResponse: Unaccompanied children entering Romania can receive help from the General Directorates for Social Assistance and Child Protection (DGASPC) from each county, which are the authorized institutions to take care of them. If there is a suspicion of child abuse, individuals can call 119, a unique national telephone number for such cases. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/dopomohaapp

answers.answer: Temporary accommodation for refugees in Romania can be found by accessing "Un Acoperiș". This service helps individuals find or provide temporary living spaces for vulnerable people arriving in Romania.
answers.bResponse: Temporary accommodation for refugees in Romania can be found by accessing "Un Acoperiș". This service helps individuals find or provide temporary living spaces for vulnerable people arriving in Romania. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/dopomohaapp

answers.answer:
Yes, there are several helplines and contact numbers for assistance in Romania.

For general support, help-lines include:
*   CNRR: 0040 730 073 170
*   UNHCR: +40723653651
*   IOM Romania: 021 210 3050
*   National Line against Trafficking in Persons Romania: 0 800 800 678 / +4021.313.31.00

For child abuse cases, the unique national telephone number is 119.

For financial-banking services assistance for Ukrainian citizens at BCR, call 0373514244.

Regional Centers for Procedures and Accommodation for Asylum Seekers also have contact numbers:
*   Rădăuți: +40 230 56 44 62, +40 230 56 44 63
*   Maramureș: +40 261 80 77 57, +40 261 80 77 77 interior 20695, 20696, 20697
*   Galați: 0236 – 323878
*   București: +40 21 240 87 74
*   Timișoara: 0256.421.240
*   Giurgiu: 0246 – 215056

answers.answer: If you have a biometric passport, you do not need a visa to travel to the EU. For specific conditions of travel to an EU Member State, it is recommended to contact the embassy of your destination country.
answers.bResponse: If you have a biometric passport, you do not need a visa to travel to the EU. For specific conditions of travel to an EU Member State, it is recommended to contact the embassy of your destination country. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/dopomohaapp

answers.answer:
The regional centers for procedures and accommodation for asylum seekers in Romania are located in:
*   Rădăuți (Str. Perilor nr.2, Rădăuți, județul Suceava)
*   Maramureș (Str. Mihai Viteazu, nr. 11, Satu Mare)
*   Galați (Str. Săvinești nr.2, Galați, județul Galaţi)
*   București (str. Tudor Gociu, nr. 24A, sector 4, București)
*   Timișoara (Str. Armoniei nr.33, Timișoara, judetul Timiș)
*   Giurgiu (Bulevardul 1907, Giurgiu, județul Giurgiu)

answers.answer: Two specific digital solutions are offered to support refugees: "Law made simple," which helps citizens better understand their rights and obligations, and "PTSD Help," a free assistant for managing Post Traumatic Stress Disorder.
